subsection.title: Cylindrical Symmetry
subsection.p:
below illustrates conditions satisfied by charge distribution that has a cylindrical symmetry. Basically, you should look for following four conditions when you are evaluating whether a given charge distribution has cylindrical symmetry.
Charges are distributed in an infintiely long cylindrical shape.
Charge density must not vary along the axis.
Charge density must not vary with direction in the plane perpendicular to the axis.
Charge density can depend upon the distance from the axis of the cylinder.

figure.caption: Cylindrical symmetry. To determine if a given charge distribution has a cylindrical symmetry, you look at the cross-section of an infinitely long cylinder. If the charge density does not depend on the polar angle of the cross-section or along the axis, then you have a cylindrical symmetry. In (a) charge density is constant in the cylinder, in (b) upper half of the cylinder has a different charge density that the lower half, in (c) left half of the cylinder has a different charge density than the right half, and in (d) charges are constant in different cylindrical rings but the density does not depend on the polar angle. Cases (a) and (d) have cylindrical symmetry, and, (b) and (c) do not.

subsection.title: Consequences of Cylindrical Symmetry
subsection.p: When a charge distribution has cylindrical symmetry, there is no preferred direction in the cross-section plane of the cylinder and there is no dependence along axis. Therefore, the magnitude of the electric field of a cylindrical symmetric situation can only be a function of the distance from the axis of the cylinder.

sidebyside.p: The direction of electric field must be perpendicular to the axis. We can see this easily from the way we found electric field of a charged wire in the last chapter. Every charge has a pairing charge in the cylinder that will cancel components of the electric field that are not perpendicular to the axis of the cylinder.

subsection.p: These observations about the expected electric field are best cast in the cylindrical coordinate system illustrated in . We use z for the axis and polar coordinates (s,\ \phi) for the radial and azimuthal angles in the xy-plane. We use letter s rather than r for the radial distance, since we would reserve r for spherical radial distance, not radial distance in the xy-plane.

figure.caption: The cylindrical coordinates consist of polar coordinates (s,\ \phi) in the cross-section plane of the cylinder and a Cartesian axis (z) along the axis of the cylinder.

subsection.p:
Using cylindrical coordinates, we can assert that in case of cylindrical symmetry, the magnitude of electric field at a point will a function on s only .
E_P = E_P(s),
and the direction will be along the radial line to the axis, either away from the axis or towards the axis, depending upon the net positive or negative charge. We can include the direction information if we use a unit vector pointed away from the axis. We denote this unit vector by \hat u_s. Then, electric field at P in vector form will be
\vec E_P = E_P(s) \hat u_s.

subsection.title: Electric Field of a Uniformly Charged Cylinder

sidebyside.p:
There are two types of points in this space, where we will find electric field.
a point P_\text{out} outside the cylinder, s \gt R, and
a point P_\text{in} inside the sphere, s \le R.

figure.caption: Electric field of a uniformly charged non-conducting cylinder increases inside the cylinder to a maximum at the surface, and then decreases as 1/s. The dashed line shows 1/s^2 for comparison of how rapidly electric field of a charged sphere drops with distance, which goes as 1/r^2. Here s is in units of R and E has been scaled to have value 1 at s=1.

subsubsection.title: Deriving Electric Field at an Outside Point by Gauss's Law
subsubsection.p:
As before, I will call electric field at an outside point as E_\text{out}. To show its functional dependence I will write the dependence on cylindrical radial distance s explicitly.
E_\text{out} = E_\text{out}(s),

Since in Gauss's law, electric field is inside an integral over a closed surface, we seek a Gaussian surface that contains point P_\text{out}, where magnitude of electric field will not change over the surface. A cylindrical surface about the same axis is a good candidate to explore.

However, unlike the situation with spherical surface, a cylindrical surface has two types of surfaces as shown in - (1) round surface at equal s all around, and (2) the two flat ends, where s goes from zero to the radius of the cylindrical surface.

figure.caption: The two types of surfaces make up the closed cylinderical Gaussian surface.

sidebyside.p: The flux in Gauss's law will be a sum of the fluxes on all of these surfaces combined. Fortuantely, the fluxes of the flat ends for cylindrical symmetry electric fields are zero due to the fact that direction of the electric field is along the surface and hence electric field lines do not pierce these surfaces. Another way to look at it is to note that dot product of the area vector and electric field is zero on these flat ends.

The flux through the circular part of the cylinder is quite easy to work out since we magnitude of electric field is same at all points, which are denoting by E_\text{out}(s), and the direction of electric field at a patch is parallel to the area vector. Using the dot product form of flux, we get
\Phi_\text{round part} = E_\text{out}(s)\times 2\pi s L.

subsubsection.p: Note that L is the height of the Gaussian cylinder, not that of the charged cylinder, which is infinitely long.

Adding up the fluxes from the round part and the at the flat ends, we get the net flux through a closed surface to be
\Phi_\text{closed surface} = E_\text{out}(s)\times 2\pi s L.

Now, we find amount of charge enclosed by the closed surface. We notice that only a length L of the charged cylinder is enclosed. Since charge density is constant here, corresponding charge is just the product of charge density and volume.
q_\text{enc} = \rho_0 \times \pi R^2 L.

Now, we use Gauss's law on flux in Eq. and enclosed charge in . to get
E_\text{out}(s)\times 2\pi s L = \frac{\rho_0 \times \pi R^2 L}{\epsilon_0}.
From this, we get the magnitude of electric field to be
E_\text{out}(s) = \frac{\rho_0}{2\epsilon_0} \frac{R^2}{s}.

subsubsection.title: Deriving Electric Field at an Inside Point by Gauss's Law

sidebyside.p:
To derive the field at an inside point, we take a Gaussian cylindrical surface whose circular surface contains the field point of interest, i.e., point P_\text{in}. We need to work out flux and enclosed charge here as well. The flux calculation is identical to the calculation given in Eq. above for P_\text{out}.
\Phi_\text{closed surface} = E_\text{in}(s)\times 2\pi s L.

subsubsection.p:
For enclosed charge, we note here that, not all charges of the cylinder of length L are enclosed. Only charges upto the radius of s are enclosed. Therefore,
q_\text{enc} = \rho_0 \times \pi s^2 L.
Now, we use them in Gauss's law to get
E_\text{in}(s)\times 2\pi s L = \frac{\rho_0 \times \pi s^2 L}{\epsilon_0}.
Solving this for E_\text{in}(s) we get
E_\text{in}(s) = \frac{\rho_0}{2\epsilon_0}\ \frac{1}{s}.

subsection.title: Gaussian Surface Selection and Flux Calculation
subsection.p: To make use of the direction and functional dependence of electric field, we choose a closed Gaussian surface in the shape of a cylinder around the axis of the cylinder of the charge distribution as shown in .

figure.caption: The Gaussian surface for finding electric field at point P in a cylindrical symmetry situation. The flux through the two flat ends is zero because \vec E is along the area, i.e., perpendicular to the area vector. Therefore, the flux through the entire Gaussian surface is simple the flux through the side, where electric field has the same magnitude, since all points of the side of the cylindrical surface are at same distance s. This gives \Phi = 2\pi s L E_P . This will be positive for the positive charges shown in the figure here, but flux will be negative if the charges in the cylinder were net negative.

subsection.p: The flux through a cylindrical Gaussian surface of radius s and height L, having the same axis as the axis of the cylinder of charge distribution, is easy to compute if we divide our task into two parts: (a) a flux through the two flat ends and a flux through the curved surface.

The flux through the flat ends must be zero since electric field is perpendicular to the area vectors of the patches on the ends.
\Phi_{\text{ends}}= 0.
The flux through the curved side of the Gaussian surface is simply the product of the magnitude of electric field E(s) at any point of this surface, including point P, and the area of the surface, since \vec E\parallel\Delta \vec A at all points.
\Phi_{\text{side}}=\sum_{\text{patches}}\vec E\cdot\Delta \vec A = E_P(s)\times 2\pi s L.
Therefore, flux through the closed cylindrical surface is
\Phi_\text{closed surface} = \Phi_\textrm{ends} + \Phi_\text{side} = E_P(s)\times 2\pi s L.

subsection.title: Using Gauss's Law in Cylindrical Symmetry Case
subsection.p:
In the cylindrical symmetry case, we found that the Gaussian surface was a cylinder of length L and radius s, whose side has the field point P. The flux through this Gaussian surface has the following form.
\Phi_E = 2\pi L s E_P,
where E_P is the magnitude of the electric field at P.

Gauss's law states that flux through a Gaussian surface is equal to q_\text{enc}/\epsilon, where q_\text{enc} is the total charge inside the volume surrounded by the Gausssian surface.
2\pi L s E_P = \dfrac{q_\text{enc}}{\epsilon_0}.

sidebyside.p:
Therefore, the magnitude of the electric field in the case of cylindrical symmetry is given by
E_P = \dfrac{1}{2\pi\epsilon_0}\, \dfrac{q_\text{enc}/L}{s}.

subsection.p:
The enclosed charge will be proportional to the length L of the Gaussian cylinder. Let's denote the enclosed charge per unit length by \lambda_\text{enc}.
q_\text{enc} = \lambda_\text{enc} L.
Then, we can write the magnitude of the electric field as
E_P = \dfrac{1}{2\pi\epsilon_0}\, \dfrac{\lambda_\text{enc}}{s}.
The direction of the electric field is away from the axis if charge is positive and towards the axis if charge is negative.

Note that electric field in the cylindrical case does not drop off as inverse of square of the distance from the charges - instead, it drops of more slowly, as o inverse distanc, not square of the distance.

exercise.title: Detemining if a Charge Distribution has Approximate Cylindrical Symmetry

statement.p:
Determine if approximate cylindrical symmetry holds for the following situations. State why or why not.
A 300-cm long copper rod of radius 1 cm is charged with +500 nC of charge and we seek electric field at a point 5 cm from the center of the rod.
A 10-cm long copper rod of radius 1 cm is charged with +500 nC of charge and we seek electric field at a point 5 cm from the center of the rod.
A 150-cm wooden rod is glued to a 150-cm plastic rod to make a 300-cm long rod, which is then painted with a charged paint so that one obtains a uniform charge density. The radius of each rod is 1 cm, and we seek an electric field at a point that is 4 cm from the center of the rod.
Same rod as ( ), but we seek electric field at a point that is 500-cm from the center of the rod.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p: (a) Yes, approximate cylindrical symmetry exists, since the distance 5 cm \lt\lt length of the rod 300 cm.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p: (b) No, cylindrical symmetry is not appropriate here, since distance to the space point, 5 cm is not much smaller than the size of the cylinder 10 cm.

solution.title: (c)
solution.p: (c) Although we have different materials, but since the charge density is uniform, the difference in material will not matter. The ends of the rod are far away, and hence cylindrical symmetry can be used in this case.

solution.title: (d)
solution.p: (d) Now, the cylindrical symmetry will not be appropriate here since ends of the cylinder are not far away compared to the distance to the space point.

exercise.title: Electric Field of a Charged Thin Long Wire

statement.p: A thin straight wire has a uniform linear charge density \lambda_0 (SI units: \text{C/m}). Find the electric field at a distance d from the wire.

answer.p: Magnitude: E = \dfrac{1}{2\pi\epsilon_0}\, \dfrac{\lambda_0}{d}, and direction away from the wire if \lambda_0\gt 0 and towards the wire if \lambda_0\lt 0.

sidebyside.p:
The given charge density has cylindrical symmetry. Therefore, electric field at a distance d from the wire will have the magnitude
E = \dfrac{1}{2\pi\epsilon_0}\, \dfrac{q_\text{enc}/L}{d},

solution.p:
where q_\text{enc} are the charges on the wire in length L.
q_\text{enc} = \lambda_0 L.

Therefore,
E = \dfrac{1}{2\pi\epsilon_0}\, \dfrac{\lambda_0}{d}.
The direction of the field is away from the wire if \lambda_0\gt 0 and towards the wire if \lambda_0\lt 0.

exercise.title: Electric Field of a Uniformly Charged Cylindrical Shell

statement.p: A non-conducting cylindrical shell of radius R has a uniform surface charge density \sigma_0 (SI units: \text{C/m}^2). Find the electric field (a) at a point outside the shell and (b) at a point inside the shell.

answer.p: (a) Magnitude \frac{2\pi R \sigma_0}{2\pi \epsilon_0}\frac{1}{s} with direction away from axis if \sigma_0 \gt 0 and towards the axis if \sigma_0 \lt 0.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p: (a) Electric field at a point outside the shell
For a point outside the cylindrical shell, the Gaussian surface will be the surface of a cylinder of radius s \gt R and length L as shown in the figure.

figure.caption: Gaussian surface for a point outside the shell.

solution.p:
The charge enclosed by the Gaussian cylinder is equal to the charge on the cylindrical shell of length L. Therefore, \lambda_\text{enc} is given by
\lambda_\text{enc} = \frac{\sigma_0\times 2\pi R L}{L} = 2\pi R \sigma_0.
Hence, the electric field at a point P outside the shell at a distance s away from the axis has the magnitude:
E_P = \frac{2\pi R \sigma_0}{2\pi \epsilon_0}\frac{1}{s} \ \ \ (s\gt R),
The electric field at P will be pointed away from the axis as given in if \sigma_0 \gt 0 , but towards the axis if \sigma_0 \lt 0.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p: (b) Electric field at a point inside the shell

For a point inside the cylindrical shell, the Gaussian surface will be a cylinder whose radius s is less than R. That means, no charges will be included inside the Gaussian surface.
\lambda_{enc} = 0.

figure.caption: Gaussian surface for a point outside the shell.

solution.p:
This gives the following equation for the magnitude of the electric field E_{in} at a point whose s is less than R of the shell of charges.
E_\text{in}\times 2\pi s L = 0\ \ \ (s\lt R),
which gives
E_\text{in} = 0\ \ \ (s\lt R).

exercise.title: Electric Field of Oppositely Charged Two Concentric Cylindrical Shells

statement.p: Figure shows two charged concentric thin cylindrical shells. There are no charges in the space at the core, i.e., charge density, \rho = 0,\ r\lt R_1 or between the shells \rho = 0,\ R_1\lt r \lt R_2. The two shells are uniformly charged with different charge densities, +\sigma_1 and -\sigma_2 such that the net charge on the two shells are equal in magnitude but opposite in sign.
There are three distinct field points, labeled, P_1, P_2, and P_3. (a) Find electric fields at these points. (b) Draw representative electric field lines for this system of charges.

How can you create this type of situation? You can start with two concentric metal cylindrical shells. Place some positive charge on inner shell and same amount on the outer shell. You can do that by connecting a positive terminal of a DC battery to the inner shell and the negative of the battery to the outer shell. This arrangement of metal shells is called a cylindrical capacitor. We will study capacitors in a future chapter.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
The given charges satisfy the condition of cylindrical symmetry. Therefore, we use Gaussian cylinders with the field point of interest (P_1,\ P_2, \text{ or } P_3) at the side of the cylinder. This will give smae formula for the magnitude of electric field at these points.
E_i = \dfrac{1}{2\pi\epsilon_0}\, \dfrac{\lambda_\text{inc,i}}{s_i}, \ \ (i=1,\ 2, \ 3),
where i refer to the three points of interest. The enclosed charges inside the Gaussian cylinders in the three cases give
\lambda_\text{inc,1} \amp = 0, \lambda_\text{inc,2} \amp = \dfrac{\sigma_1 \times 2\pi R_1 L}{L}, \lambda_\text{inc,3} \amp = \dfrac{\sigma_1 \times 2\pi R_1 L - \sigma_2 \times 2\pi R_2 L}{L} = 0.
Therefore, the magnitudes of electric fields at these points are
E_1 \amp = 0, E_2 \amp = \dfrac{\sigma_1 R_1}{\epsilon_0}\, \dfrac{1}{s_1}, E_3 \amp = 0.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p: In the present situaion, electric field is non-zero only between the shells with direction radially outward from the positive shell to the negative shell. It is better to draw these lines in a cross-section plane of the cylinder.
